stories.text:
I'm a small shareholder in a private startup.

Recently the company has amended the shareholders agreement, to grant themselves:

* Right of first refusal on stock sales.

* To implement a drag-along-right.

I'm not sure that I should sign the new agreement, since it mostly seems to amount to imposing lots of new restrictions on how I should sell my shares.

A bit more information:

* My shares are non voting.

* The company has several classes of shares. Mine are likely not the best class. (I'd need to do more research to determine where my class of shares stands relative to the other classes.)

I have no further information on what the company now intends to do, whether it be to go public, sell to another company.

The only reason I can think of for signing is so that my class of shares gets a fair price if they are considering a private sale. I can imagine them refusing a favourable price to minority holdouts in such a case.

Another outcome might be that I get stuck with an illiquid stock in some other private company.

If, on the other hand, they go public, then my shares might become much more valuable.

Aside, for "consult a lawyer" does anyone have any ideas/advice?
